INTRODUCTION
This appeal stems from divorce proceedings between Christopher
Blaine McGregor (“the father”) and Brittany Michelle Gilliland (“the
mother”). Christopher McGregor filed for divorce after he discovered
Brittany had been abusing their minor daughter to the point that there
were marks on her. Ample testimony showed that the abuse occurred,
that the children were more comfortable with their father, and that the
father was more capable of looking after them than was the mother.
Based on the ore tenus rule, the evidence adduced at court and the fact
that some of the evidence the trial court based its decision on was not
present in the record on appeal, the trial court’s decision to award the
father sole physical custody of the children was justified. The appeal
should be denied.
STATEMENT OF THE CASE
The father and the mother were married in May 2018. R. 12.
Two children resulted from the marriage, A.K., a daughter, born May 24,
2012 and B.M., a son, born May 10, 2018. (“daughter” and “son”
respectively.)
6
On August 18, 2023, the father filed for divorce from the mother on
the grounds of incompatibility. R. 12-14. In the complaint for divorce,
the father asked for custody of the minor children with the mother to be
allowed visitation. R. 13. At the same time, the father moved for
emergency ex parte pendente lite relief, alleging that the mother had
“recently caused physical injury to [the daughter] by striking or grabbing
her in a way that left bruises or other marks on said child.” R. 14. The
petition also alleged that because the son was only four years old, he
would not be able to adequately articulate facts if he were subject to
physical abuse. R. 15. Finally, the petition also alleged that the
mother “has been acting erratically regarding the discipline of the
parties’ children within the last year.” R. 15. The trial judge issued a
pendente lite order the same day granting the father physical custody of
the minor children and setting the “matter” for hearing on September 12,
2023. R. 17. The mother filed an answer and counterclaim for divorce
on September 8, 2023. R. 19. Her counterclaim alleged that the father
was “manipulative and controlling,” that he “refused to allow [her] to
have a bank account,” and that he “constantly berated her in front of the
7
children.” R. 20. The same day, the mother also requested pendente
lite relief. R. 23.
The trial court held a pendente lite hearing on all parties’ motions
on September 12, 2023. R. 27. At the pendente lite hearing, the trial
court heard testimony ore tenus. R. 47. No transcript or summary of
the testimony was provided in the court record by the mother, appellee.
The pendente lite order stated that the parties would share legal custody
of the minor children with primary placement with the father and set
forth a visitation schedule for the mother. R. 47.
The final hearing on the initial divorce was held on November 6,
2023. T. 1. The trial court took testimony from numerous witnesses.
In addition, the parties agreed that the Court would adopt the “full-
fledged” pendente lite hearing and consider the testimony there in
making his decision. T. 19. At the pendente lite hearing, the trial
judge heard from the daughter. T. 13. With the permission of both
parties, the trial judge spoke to the daughter in chambers without a court
reporter present. S1.1
1 On January 8, 2025, the father filed a motion to supplement the
8
On February 1, 2024, the trial judge entered a “final decree of
divorce.” R. 83-90. However, that order was set aside by the trial court
as being “entered in error.” R. 91. Instead, the final decree of divorce
was entered on February 27, 2024. R. 92-99. Pertinent to the child
custody issues raised by the mother in her appeal, the trial court ruled:
1) The parents were awarded “joint legal custody” of both
children. R. 95.
2) The mother was given visitation periods the first and third
weeks of each month from “picking up the children on Thursday at school
until taking the children back to school the following Monday morning”
on those weeks. R. 95. The mother was further allowed visitation for
an entire week during the first and third full weeks of June and July. R.
95. Arrangements were made for holiday visitation as well. R. 97.
Further, each parent was given the right to “call or Facetime with the
record on appeal with the trial court to include the following statement:
“In addition to the materials contained in the record, as part of making
its decision on the original divorce decree, the Court spoke to the minor
children separately in chambers without either counsel or a court
reporter present. This was done with the permission of all parties.”
Should the motion be granted, the citation for this information will be
provided once the supplemental record is compiled.
9
minor children once a day while the child is with the other parent.” R.
97. The mother was ordered to pay child support in the amount of $ 617
per month for both children. R. 97. The trial court did not find that the
father had committed domestic abuse of the mother.
STATEMENT OF THE ISSUE
1) Did sufficient evidence support the trial court’s award of physical
custody of both children to the father?
STATEMENT OF FACTS
At the trial of this matter, the trial court heard conflicting
testimony on matters relevant to child custody, including testimony not
presented in the record on appeal, such as the testimony at the pendente
lite hearing and the trial court’s conversations with the minor children.
The parties agreed that the daughter and the son are their natural
children and that the daughter was born on May 24, 2012 and the son on
May 10, 2019. R. 7. Other than that, they presented conflicting
testimony on who took primary care of the children, whether the mother
had abused the daughter, whether the mother cared for the children as
primary custodian, and whether the father had abused the mother.
10
A. There Was Conflicting Testimony About Who Took
Primary Care of the Children
The father testified that when both the father and the mother were
employed, they acted as a team, cleaning the house together. However,
when the mother lost her job, the mother stopped doing anything in the
house. “The house was not kept up. There were always dishes in the
sink, loads of clothes on the bed.” T. 14. At that point, the father did
most of the house-cleaning with help from the father’s mother, Lisa. T.
14. The father testified as well that he did 90% of the cooking. T. 14.
This included lunch and dinner and all of the grocery shopping for both
meals. T. 14. In addition, he did about seventy percent of the clothes
washing. Id. The father further testified that once the mother was not
working, she did take care of the children’s doctor’s appointments. Id.,
14-15.
Lisa McGregor, the father’s mother, testified that over the years,
the father did the cooking. T. 111-112. Ms. McGregor had the
opportunity to observe the family both as a visitor and as residents, since
the family had lived with her on and off over the years. T. 111-112. She
testified that the father has a great relationship with his children, helps
11
the daughter with her homework, feeds them, buys snacks for them,
cooks for them and washes clothes. T. 112.
In contrast, the mother testified that she took care of most of the
regular day-to-day care of the daughter from the time of the daughter’s
birth, although the father participated. T. 152. This day-to-day care
included giving the daughter a bath, taking her to the doctor, washing
clothes, preparing meals and taking her to dental and hair cut
appointments, as well as registering her for school. T. 152. The mother
also testified that she made bottles and changed the son’s diapers. T.
164. Both parties agreed that the mother took the kids to school before
their separation. T. 14.
Regarding a support system to help with the children, the father
testified that the mother does not have a support system because she had
no relationship with either her mother or father. T. 45. The father has
his mother, his father, his brother and his sister-in-law who can help him.
T. 37. The mother testified that she “had really great friends, but no
family,” although she later added that she did have brothers and sisters.
T. 176, 192.
12
B. There Was Conflicting Testimony Whether the Mother
Had Hurt The Daughter Physically and Mentally
The parties disagreed over whether the mother had abused the
daughter. The father testified that he filed for divorce immediately
when he saw the mother hurt the daughter for the first time. T. 8-9.
He heard the daughter screaming. T. 8-9. When the father walked into
the bedroom, he saw that the mother had the daughter up against the
wall, and slapped her in the face, hit her in the mouth, and pulled her by
the hair into the living room. T. 8-9. The father testified that the
mother had told him that “in her opinion, it was okay to slap a kid or pop
them in the mount if they smarted off to the adult.” T. 9. The father
entered into an evidence a photograph taken after the mother and the
daughter had been in the basement practicing for a national dance
competition and the mother thought the daughter wasn’t putting enough
effort into the practice. T. 10. The photograph shows that Addie’s arm
had bruises and marks. Id. There was another photograph, Exhibit 10,
that the father submitted that he testified showed further marks on the
daughter. T. 12. For a long time, the father thought that the marks in
13
that photo were made by someone at school, but he found out later that
the mother made the marks. T. 12.
One of the mother’s witnesses, Porcsha Caldwell, testified that she
received a phone call from the mother before the divorce where the
mother asked her if she had ever “popped” her child in the mouth. Ms.
Caldwell answered, saying “If you just mean a little, you know, stop
talking to me that way slight pop in the mouth, nothing to hurt her, then
yes, I have.” T. 218. The mother then responded to someone else,
presumably the father, not on the telephone call, “See, I’m not the only
one…” Ms. Caldwell then heard the father say, “Porcsha can discipline
her children how she wants to, but you’re not going to slap my child in
the face.” T. 219. Porcsha then said “I did not say I have ever slapped
my child in the face. I do not agree with that. I have lightly popped her
in the mouth, and that was the extent of it.” T. 219.
On the other hand, the mother testified that she believed that the
daughter had been coached to say that the mother had caused the marks
on her arm. T. 204-205. She also testified that she did not cause any
of the injuries in the photographs to the daughter in any form or
14
fashion. T. 174. The mother testified that it was L.M., the daughter’s
cousin with Down’s Syndrome, who had caused the marks on the
daughter’s arms in that the two liked to “rough house.” T. 173.2
“There’s been instances where he’s slapped at her arm. He’s scratched
her, scratched her friends.” T. 173. However, on at least one occasion
when L.M. supposedly had hurt the daughter rough housing with her,
L.M.’s parents could prove that L.M. was nowhere near the daughter on
that day. On March 15, one of the days the marks appeared on the
daughter’s arms, it was spring break in Alex City and L.M. had been with
his maternal grandparents and his sister, not with the daughter. T. 125.
And that evening, from 4:00 p.m. to 8:30 p.m., he was at the baseball field
in his capacity as manager of the middle school’s baseball team. T. 125.
Thus, it would have been physically impossible for L.M. to have caused
the marks on the daughter. T. 126. L.M.’s mother testified that she
had never seen L.M. be inappropriately rough with the daughter at any
time. R. 127.
2 L.M. is the father’s nephew, the son of the father’s brother Brian and
sister-in-law, Katie. T. 126.
15
With respect to mental abuse, the father’s mother, Lisa McGregor,
explained that the mother found it frustrating to help the daughter with
her homework. Lisa explained, “She cannot comprehend that [the
daughter’s] not as smart – everybody has a different way of learning, I
guess, you know, and it takes a little bit more time for [the daughter.]”
T. 113. Lisa also testified that the mother had told her, when trying to
help the daughter with her homework, “I can’t do this.” T. 113. Lisa
testified that the mother “gets too frustrated trying to help [the daughter]
do homework.” T. 113. Lisa has heard the mother call Addie stupid.
T. 114. The father testified that the mother would get “absolutely
distraught” helping the daughter with her homework and so would call
her “stupid and it would escalate from there.” T. 41. He has also seen
the mother yank food out of the daughter’s hands, telling the daughter
she would get fat and doing so would affect her dancing career. T. 41.
The father testified that he has seen the mother grab one of the family
dogs by the neck and fling it onto the floor, while the daughter screamed
and told the mother she shouldn’t have done that.” T. 42-43.
Mother’s witnesses were mainly individuals she knew through her
16
daughter’s participation in a traveling dance team. T. 135, 211. One
such friend, Tasha Howell, testified that over the last four- or five-years
during competition season, she and the mother and their children might
be together five to six weekends in the spring and “then we have different
various things through the year.” T. 136. On those occasions, Ms.
Howell has never seen the mother lose her temper with the daughter. T.
137. However, Ms. Howell testified that she “supposes” that the mother
has a good relationship with the daughter. T. 138. However, all three
of the mother’s witnesses, Howell, Caldwell and Stacy Green, testified
that the marks in the Exhibit 9 photograph, if made by a parent, were
inappropriate and should never be made. T. 140, 146-147, 223.
C. There Was Conflicting Evidence on the Issue of
Whether the Mother Exhibited Signs of Mental
Instability While Arguing with the Father
While the mother claimed that the father abused her, evidence on
that point in fact showed the mother’s instability when her temper was
aroused. The mother claimed that the father had hit her on the forehead
with a laptop during an argument. T. 167-169. According to the
mother, the father took her phone, and she followed him upstairs trying
17
to get it back. T. 167-169. While trying to do so, she snatched the
laptop up, he snatched it back and hit her over the head with it. T. 167-
169. She also testified that the father has shoved her and pushed the
couch over, making her fall to the floor. T. 169.
However, the father testified that he had been upstairs in the office
and the mother came upstairs screaming and pushed him out of his
computer chair. When she did so, the computer equipment came over
on top of him and her. “She did pull it. All the computer equipment
came over on top of us and … the kids had made it upstairs by that time
and they were standing their screaming.” T. 15. The father testified
that he sent the daughter to go get his brother, who lived next door, for
help, which she did. T. 15.
Incidents like this so traumatized the daughter that she had a
secret “emoji” code with her aunt, Katie McGregor, where the daughter
could let her aunt know without interference if she needed help. T. 130.
That way, the daughter always knew somebody could come help her if
she needed it. T. 131. Katie testified that it was “almost always” the
mother that upset the daughter that way rather than the father. T. 131.
18
D. There Was Conflicting Evidence On the Discipline
Issues Surrounding Cell Phones and Other Gifts
Another area of disagreement between the father and the mother
was whether the father gave too many gifts to the daughter. The mother
testified that the father gave the daughter a cell phone when she was
seven against her wishes. T. 165. However, the father testified that it
was a joint decision. T. 73. “[the daughter] had an iPad, the iPad with
the carrier was up for renewal, and in the store that day, based off
whatever promotion they had, there was no iPad promotion, and she got
a phone.” T. 73. The mother testified that the father failed to monitor
the daughter’s cell phone and would return it to the daughter against her
wishes even if it had been taken away for discipline. T. 165. However,
the father testified that he did monitor the daughter’s cell phone. T. 75.
In addition, he testified that both parents would take it away for
disciplinary purposes if needed, including one time for more than a
month. T. 75-76.
The mother also implied that the father gave the daughter gifts that
were too expensive during the pendency of the divorce, such as pajamas
and makeup, as well as promising her Taylor Swift tickets, as compared
19
to the gifts that the son received. T. 184. However, in doing so, she has
overlooked the fact that the son is only four, and so age-appropriate
presents are correspondingly less expensive. T. 206. In addition, as
the mother admitted, at least two years of the son’s first four years fell
during the COVID pandemic, during which time little was happening
anywhere. T. 206.
E. The Testimony of Heather Dixon, The Daughter’s
Counselor, Supports Giving Physical Custody to The
Father.
At the November hearing, the trial court heard testimony from
Heather Dixon, a professional counselor treating the daughter. At the
time of the hearing, she had completed four sessions with the daughter.
T. 85-86. She had also met both the father and the mother, although she
had conducted no joint sessions. T. 86, 88.
In her opinion, the daughter has issues with her mother and is
afraid of her. T. 87. Ms. Dixon is a mandatory reporter and based on
her conversations with the daughter, she did report the mother to DHR.
T. 88. Ms. Dixon has concerns about granting the mother custody of the
children. In particular, she is concerned about the “alleged abuse. If
20
she is able to become that angry and lose self-control, what may happen
to the children?” T. 89. She believed that the father’s concerns about
the welfare of the children in the mother’s hands were valid. T. 96. In
addition, her goal as a therapist is to repair the relationship between the
daughter and the mother. As she stated, “The relationship needs to be
repaired; the events that made [the daughter] scared … need to be talked
through and some repairs made.” T. 88. The daughter has stated that
she does not want the mother with her during the sessions. T. 88.
Based on the foregoing, giving the conflicting evidence and the
evidence not included with the record on the appeal, the trial court’s
judgment is support and the appeal must be denied.
STATEMENT OF THE STANDARD OF REVIEW
The standard of review in a child custody case is well settled.
“When evidence in a child custody case has been presented ore tenus to
the trial court, that court’s findings of fact based on that evidence are
presumed to be correct. The trial court is in the best position to make a
custody determination—it hears the evidence and observes the
witnesses.” Ex parte Bryowski, 676 So. 2d 1322, 1324 (Ala. 1996).
21
“Where a trial court does not make specific findings of fact concerning an
issue, this Court will assume that the trial court made those findings
necessary to support its judgment, unless such findings would be clearly
erroneous.” Ex parte Fann, 810 So. 2d 631 (Ala. 2001).
“Appellate courts do not sit in judgment of disputed evidence that
was presented ore tenus before the trial court in a custody hearing.” Id.
In other words, an appellate court “will not reverse unless the evidence
so fails to support the determination that is plainly and palpably wrong,
or unless an abuse of the trial court’s discretion is shown. To substitute
our judgment for that of the trial court would be to reweigh the evidence.
This Alabama law does not allow.” Id.
Moreover, “this presumption is based on the trial court's unique
position to directly observe the witnesses and to assess their demeanor
and credibility. This opportunity to observe witnesses is especially
important in child-custody cases. ‘In child custody cases especially, the
perception of an attentive trial judge is of great importance.’” Corbitt v.
Corbitt, 369 So. 3d 1078, 1088 (Ala. Civ. App. 2022).
“When the trial court makes an initial custody determination,
22
neither party is entitled to a presumption in his or her favor, and the ‘best
interest of the child’ standard will generally apply.” Robinson v.
Robinson, --- So. 3d ---, No. CL-2024-0074, 2024 WL 4096263 at * 9 (Ala.
Civ. App. 2024). There are several factors a trial court may consider in
making the initial award of custody, including the “characteristics of
those seeking custody, including age, character, stability, mental and
physical health ... [and] the interpersonal relationship between each
child and each parent.” Id. Extra factors might include the sex and age
of the children, and each parent’s ability to provide for their needs, but
the “overall focus of the trial court’s decision is the best interests and
welfare of the children.” Id., quoting Steed v. Steed, 877 So. 2d 602, 604
(Ala. Civ. App. 2003).
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT
The mother’s appeal should be denied.
First, the appellate courts have long held that “the judgment of a
trial court which is based on evidence heard by it but which is not
included in the record on appeal cannot be disturbed by the appellate
court where one of the grounds of appeal is the sufficient of the evidence
23
to support such judgment.” Bynum v. Bynum, 296 So. 2d 711, 725 (Ala.
Civ. App. 1974). In reaching its decision, the trial court considered
evidence adduced at the pendente lite hearing as well as a conversation
in chambers with the children. T. 13, 19, S1.3 This evidence is not part
of the trial record and thus the mother’s appeal, based on the sufficiency
of the evidence, must be denied.
There was substantial evidence from which the Court could have
found that the mother abused the daughter. There was testimony from
both the father, Lisa McGregor who is the father’s mother, and the
daughter’s counselor regarding physical and mental abuse that took
place which supported the Court’s awarding physical custody to the
father. T. 8-9, 10, 12, 41, 42-43, 113, 114. 218-219
In addition, there was substantial evidence from which the trial
3 On January 8, 2025, the father filed a motion to supplement the
record on appeal with the trial court to include the following statement:
“In addition to the materials contained in the record, as part of making
its decision on the original divorce decree, the Court spoke to the minor
children separately in chambers without either counsel or a court
reporter present. This was done with the permission of all parties.”
Should the motion be granted, the citation for this information will be
provided once the supplemental record is compiled.
24
court found that it was in the best interest of the children to award the
father primary physical custody. In addition to the evidence above
showing the mother abused the daughter physically and mentally, there
was evidence that the father did most of the house-cleaning, cooking and
laundry. T. 14, 15, 111-112. In addition, the father has a robust
support system through his mother, father, brother and sister-in-law to
help him with the children, T. 37, 45. Descriptions of arguments the
couple had while married tend to show the mother’s instability when her
temper was aroused. T. 15. On one such occasion, the daughter
became so scared that her aunt, Katie McGregor, arranged for a secret
“emoji” code the daughter could send if she needed help to reassure her.
T. 130, 131. Heather Dixon, the counselor who is treating the daughter,
testified that the father’s concerns about the welfare of the children in
the mother’s hands were valid, especially considering the mother’s
temper. T. 89, 96.
The appeal should be denied.
ARGUMENT
The trial court’s order granting physical custody of the children to
25
the father should be affirmed. First, since the judgment of the trial
court relied on evidence heard by the trial court but not present in the
record, the appellate court cannot disturb the judgment. Bynum v.
Bynum, 296 So. 2d 711, 725 (Ala. Civ. App. 1974). Second, there was
substantial evidence from which the trial court could have found that the
mother was physically and mentally abusive toward the daughter.
Finally, there was substantial evidence that granting the father primary
physical custody of the children was in their best interest. The divorce
decree should be affirmed.
A. Evidence Heard by the Trial Court is Not Present
in the Record on Appeal, Requiring the Trial
Court’s Judgment to be Affirmed
In addition to the final hearing held on November 6, 2023, the Court
held a prior pendente lite hearing on September 12, 2023. R. 27. That
hearing included ore tenus testimony. R. 47. It also included an in
camera conversation between the trial judge and the children.
Q. Okay, and we filed an ex parte thing, and we had
already had the hearing on it, I think, where the Judge
heard from your daughter; is that correct?
A. Yes, sir.
26
T. 13.
At the final hearing, the parties agreed that the testimony and
evidence taken at the pendente lite hearing would be part of the basis
used by the trial court for making its rulings in the final hearing.
Mr. Young (Counsel for the father):
And, Judge, a lot of these things are what we’ve introduced
before. I don’t know if the Court wants to take judicial notice
of what you got before, but I’ll be glad to go into them again.
Mr. Radney (Counsel for the mother):
Judge, I have no objection to you adopting the full-fledged
pendente lite hearing and considering it as a part of this.
The Court: All right. Let’s do that.
Mr. Young: That’s fine with me, Judge. Thank you.
T. 19.
In addition, a motion to supplement the record is pending before
the trial court. The supplement will state:
In addition to the materials contained in the record, as part of
making its decision in the original divorce decree, the Court
spoke to the minor children separately in chambers without
either counsel or a court reporter present. This was done
with the permission of all parties.
S1. (The correct record citation will be added once the supplement is
27
approved and prepared.)
Neither the testimony from the pendente lite hearing, nor the
conversations the judge had with the children, are part of the record on
appeal. Since the trial judge considered evidence that is not part of the
appellate record, and since the mother’s grounds for appeal are based on
the sufficiency of the evidence, the trial court’s order should be affirmed.
In Bynum v. Bynum, 296 So. 2d 722 (Ala. Civ. App. 1974), the Court
of Civil Appeals reviewed a trial court’s award of custody of a six-year-
old boy to his father. As part of the hearing, the trial court conducted a
private interview of the child in camera without the parents present. No
one objected. In fact, the trial judge spoke to the child twice, three days
apart. Bynum, 296 So. 2d at 723. The trial judge announced that he
had reduced the substance of those two conversations to writing and
sealed them in an envelope. Id. The writing was to remain secret if
there was not an appeal but if an appeal occurred, the judge’s statement
was to be placed in the record. Id. The attorney for the mother objected
to including the statement in the record, but the trial judge put it in
anyhow. Id. at 723-724. On appeal, the appellate court first explained
28
that “the practice of trial courts interviewing minors In camera in custody
cases is widespread and well-known and has a beneficent purpose, for it
is believed that a fuller disclosure can be obtained in such examination
than if the child is examined in open court with both parents confronting
him.” Id. at 724. The court then observed that “the judgment of a trial
court which is based on evidence heard by it, but which is not included in
the record on appeal cannot be disturbed by the appellate court where
one of the grounds of appeal is the sufficiency of the evidence to support
said judgment.” Id. at 725. Thus, it explained, even had the trial court
NOT placed its written statement into the record, the appellate court
would have had to affirm the judgment.
Similarly, in the instant case, not only is the conversation the trial
judge had with the children not in the record, but also the ore tenus
testimony taken as part of the pendente lite hearing and incorporated
into the final hearing is missing from the record. The judgment should be
affirmed.
In Johnson v. Johnson, 395 So. 2d 1043 (Ala. Civ. App. 1981), the
appellate court used similar reasoning to affirm an award of the custody
29
of two daughters to their father. While recognizing there was “ample
evidence that the mother is a loving and caring mother,” the court also
noted that “there was evidence before the trial court which is not before
this court; i.e., the in camera conversation with the children.” Johnson,
395 So. 2d at 1044. The court continued:
It has long been established that this court may not disturb a
trial court's finding of fact ‘where there was evidence before
the trial court which may have influenced it in arriving at its
finding of fact and which is not before us.’
Johnson, 395 So. 2d at 1044-1045, quoting Hagler v. Hagler, 278 So. 2d
715 (1973).
Since the trial considered testimony and evidence in making its
ruling not before the appellate court here, and since the mother’s appeal
is based on sufficiency of the evidence grounds, the trial court’s opinion
is due to be affirmed.
B. There Was Substantial Evidence From Which The
Court Could Have Found That The Mother Abused The
Daughter.
The mother argues, somewhat confusingly, that a rebuttable
presumption that she was not entitled to obtain custody of the children
due to domestic abuse was refuted and the trial court erred in granting
30
physical custody to the father. However, the issue before this Court is
whether there was substantial evidence from which the trial court could
have found it was in the daughter’s best interest for the father to have
physical custody of the daughter based on the mother’s treatment of
daughter.
“Determination of child custody rests in the sound discretion of the
trial court and the exercise of such discretion will not be reversed except
for plain and palpable abuse. Furthermore, there is a strong
presumption favoring the trial court’s finding in child custody cases.”
Johnson v. Johnson, 395 So. 2d 1043, 1044 (Ala. Civ. App. 1981). “This
presumption is based on the trial court’s unique position to directly
observe the witnesses and to assess their demeanor and credibility.”
Corbitt v. Corbitt, 369 So. 2d 1078, 1088 (Ala. Civ. App. 2022).
In addition to whatever testimony outside of the record on appeal
the judge considered, there was ample testimony in the record to support
a finding that the mother had harmed the daughter both physically and
mentally. The father testified that the event that triggered his filing for
divorce was his personally observing the mother harming the daughter.
31
T. 8-9. Walking into a room, the father saw that the mother had the
daughter up against the wall, slapping her in the face, hitting her in the
mouth and then pulling her by the hair into the living room. T. 8-9.
The father testified that the mother had told him she felt it was okay to
slap a child if they smarted off to an adult. T. 9. There were two
photographs entered into evidence that showed injuries to the daughter,
and evidence to support a finding that the mother caused those injuries.
T. 9, 10, 12. One of the mother’s witnesses testified that the mother
called her to ask if she ever “popped” her daughter in the mouth, and
during the conversation heard the father exclaim that regardless of what
others did, “you’re not going to slap my child in the face.” T. 219. The
daughter’s aunt testified that the daughter was so frightened of her
mother especially that the aunt and the daughter established an emoji
code that the daughter could use to send for help from her phone. T.
130.
Lisa McGregor’s, the father’s mother, explained that the mother
found it frustrating to help the daughter with her homework. As she
explained, ““She cannot comprehend that [the daughter’s] not as smart –
32
everybody has a different way of learning, I guess, you know, and it takes
a little bit more time for [the daughter.]” T. 113. Lisa also testified that
the mother had told her, when trying to help the daughter with her
homework, “I can’t do this.” T. 113. Lisa testified that the mother “gets
too frustrated trying to help [the daughter] do homework.” T. 113. Lisa
has heard the mother call Addie stupid. T. 114. The father testified
that the mother would get “absolutely distraught” helping the daughter
with her homework and so would call her “stupid and it would escalate
from there.” T. 41. He has also seen the mother yank food out of the
daughter’s hands, telling the daughter she would get fat and doing so
would affect her dancing career. T. 41. The father testified that he has
seen the mother grab one of the family dogs by the neck and fling it onto
the floor, while the daughter screamed and told the mother she shouldn’t
have done that.” T. 42-43.
The daughter’s therapist, Heather Dixon, testified that in her
professional opinion, the daughter has issues with the mother and fears
her. T. 87. Some actions the daughter told her about concerned Ms.
Dixon enough she reported the mother to DHR, although no further
33
actions were taken. T. 88. Ms. Dixon’s concerns about granting the
mother custody of the children centered on the “alleged abuse.” T. 89.
“If she is able to become that angry and lose self-control, what may
happen to the children?” T. 89. Thus, the therapist believed that the
father’s concerns about the welfare of the children were valid. T. 96.
The fact that evidence was also adduced to the contrary is not
enough to overturn the trial court’s ruling. “Appellate courts do not sit
in judgment of disputed evidence that was presented ore tenus before the
trial court in a custody hearing.” Ex parte Bryowski, 676 So. 2d 1322,
1324 (Ala. 1996). There was substantial evidence to support the award
of physical custody of the children to the father.
34
C. Substantial Evidence Supported the Judge’s Finding That
It Was in the Best Interest of the Children to Award the
Father Custody
The factors that a trial judge is to consider in making an initial
award of custody in a divorce proceeding include the age, character,
stability, mental and physical health, and the ability to provide for the
needs of the children of the people seeking custody. Robinson v.
Robinson, --- So. 3d ---, No. CL-202-0074, 2024 WL 4098283 at *9 (Ala.
Civ. App. 2024). A court also may consider the sex and age of the
children. Id. But the “overall focus of the trial court’s decision is the
best interests and welfare of the children.” Id., quoting Steed v. Steed,
877 So. 2d 602, 604 (Ala. Civ. App. 2003). The hearing gave the trial
court more than enough to support its implicit finding that the best
interests and welfare of the children lie in granting the father primary
custody of the children.
In addition to the evidence of mental and physical damage
discussed above, there was testimony that once she lost her job, the
mother stopped doing anything around the house, leaving dishes in the
sink and loads of clothes on the bed. T. 14. At that time, the father
35
began doing most of the house-cleaning with help from his mother. T.
14. He also did ninety percent of the cooking, including lunch and
dinner, as well as the grocery shopping. Id. He does about seventy
percent of the clothes washing as well. Id. The father’s mother
testified that the father has a great relationship with both children, helps
the daughter with her homework, feeds the children, buys snacks for
them, and washes their clothes. T. 112. The father also has a strong
support system that will help him with the children’s needs, including
his mother, his father, his brother, and his sister-in-law. T. 37. The
mother, unfortunately, does not. T. 45. There was evidence showing
the father appropriately disciplined the children, such as monitoring the
daughter’s cell phone and taking it away from her if necessary. T. 75-
76.
The father continues to live in the marital home, but there is some
question about whether the mother has a permanent residence. She
testified that she was living at 341 Sanford Road, a house owned by Tracy
Brown, who is her friend Porcsha Caldwell’s mother. T. 148, 220.
However, no written lease for the house was put into evidence and on at
36
least one occasion, the mother was asked to find somewhere else to stay
for the night. T. 224. The father was concerned that the mother would
be sleeping in her car that evening, although he later discovered that the
mother had stayed with a friend’s brother. T. 44.
There also was testimony from which the trial judge could have
found that the mother was not emotionally stable. For example, while
the mother claimed that the father hit her on the head with a laptop, the
father testified that the incident occurred because the mother lost
control. One day the father was in his office and the mother came
upstairs screaming and fighting and pushed him out of the computer
chair, pulling the computer equipment over on top of the two. T. 15.
The children saw the fight and were standing there screaming.
Ultimately the daughter went to get the father’s brother for help. T. 15.
After the fight, the mother took the son, leaving the daughter there, and
left the house. T. 16.
On another occasion, late at night, the mother was in a foul mood,
so the father went upstairs. T. 42. He was eating a hot dog, and the
mother came upstairs and slapped the father across the face and slapped
37
the hot dog out of his hand. T. 42. In another incident, the father heard
the daughter say, “You shouldn’t have done that,” and he entered the
room to discover that the mother had picked up the dog by the neck and
flung it on the floor. T. 42-43.
There was ample evidence in the record on which the trial court
could have based its decision that the father should have primary
physical custody of the children. The trial court’s divorce decree should
be affirmed.
